subj-group.subject: Special Issue on the Personality Inventory for DSM-5

title-group.article-title: Introduction to Special Issue on the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 (PID-5)

author-notes.corresp: R. Michael Bagby, 1265 Military Trail, Toronto, Ontario, Canada M1C 1A4. Email: rmbagby@utsc.utoronto.ca

body.p: The fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5; American Psychiatric Association [APA]) was released in May 2013. Although there have been many controversies surrounding various aspects of this new diagnostic manual, perhaps none have been as contentious as the various models that have been proposed to replace the DSM-IV personality disorder (PD) system. In the end, the Board of Trustees of the American Psychiatric Association decided to maintain the current DSM-IV PD system to categorize and diagnose personality disorders in DSM-5.0. This decision was disappointing to many, but the long hard work of the Personality and Personality Disorders (P&PD) work group was not entirely without cause or result. The empirically indisputable superiority of a dimensional approach to conceptualizing and assessing personality psychopathology was highlighted for members of audiences that previously may not have been so exposed. One of the other positive outcomes of the P&PD work group (and their consultants) was the creation of a new dimensional model of personality psychopathology, which will likely provide the foundational template in how personality disorders will be conceptualized and diagnosed in subsequent revisions of the DSM-5 (e.g., DSM-5.1 or DSM-5.2). The P&PD work group and their consultants also developed a self-report instrument to operationalize and assess this model—the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 (PID-5; Krueger, Derringer, Markon, Watson, & Skodol, 2012). Even before the P&PD work group finished their deliberations, Krueger and colleagues disseminated their 220-item, self-report measure widely and researchers began to examine the validity and reliability of this instrument, and preparing manuscripts to report their results. Many of these investigators submitted their work to Assessment and on inquiry others were encouraged to do so. As the number of submissions increased, I made the decision, with the support of SAGE, the publisher of Assessment, to dedicate a special issue of Assessment to the PID-5. All these submissions were peer reviewed, and in instances where I, or any member of the editorial board, were an author or coauthor on a submission, a “masked” and conflict-free process of review was implemented.

In this special issue, there are 10 articles addressing various aspects of the validity and reliability of the PID-5. I summarize briefly the contribution of these articles below. Hopwood et al. (2013) examine the relationship between the PID-5 and the Personality Assessment Inventory (PAI), and Anderson et al. (2013), in similar vein, explore the empirical association between the PSY-5r scales of the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory-2 Restructured Form (MMPI-2-RF). The PAI and MMPI-2-RF are frequently and widely used measures of personality and psychopathology and either one of them is likely to be part of the armamentarium of diagnostic tools and psychological tests that assessment psychologists have in their offices or labs. These articles, therefore, provide information on the validity of the PID-5 in relation to constructs familiar to many practicing clinicians in addition to personality and psychopathology researchers.

De Fruyt et al. (2013) and Thomas et al. (2013) explore relations between the traits of the PID-5 and the traits of the Five Factor Model (FFM) as measured by the NEO-3, an updated version of the Revised NEO Personality Inventory; the FFM had, arguably, a predominant influence on the PID-5 and the model of personality psychopathology it operationalizes. Watson, Stasik, Ro, and Clark (2013) continue the theme of exploring the relations between “normal” and pathological personality traits touched on by both De Fruyt et al. (2013) and Thomas et al. (2013).

Strickland, Drislane, Lucy, Krueger, and Patrick (2013) and Wright et al. (2013) explore how the PID-5 can be used to capture and conceptualize specific personality psychopathology constructs (i.e., psychopathy and narcissistic personality disorder). These articles provide, to my mind, excellent procedural roadmaps to understanding categorically diagnosed PDs using dimensional traits from the PID-5.

Samuel, Hopwood, Krueger, Thomas, and Ruggero (2013) explore different approaches in how to use the 25 facet traits to diagnose PDs. The manner in how the facet traits from the PID-5 are configured to confer a personality disorder is a critical aspect of the proposed “hybrid” dimensional/categorical model, and the report by Samuel et al. is a start to addressing this issue. Quilty, Ayearst, Chmielewski, Pollock, and Bagby (2013) provide the psychometric properties of the PID-5 in a sample of psychiatric patients who participated in the APA DSM-5 Field Trial. This is an important contribution as, in the end, this instrument will be used in clinical populations, and practicing assessment psychologists need to be assured that the validity of the PID-5 extends beyond student and community populations, which to date have been the samples employed by most researchers using the PID-5 (see, however, Watson et al., 2013).

Markon, Quilty, Bagby, and Krueger (2013) outline and report on the development and validation of an informant-report form of the PID-5 (the PID-5-IRF). Multi-method assessment is critically important in psychodiagnosis most generally, but perhaps carries even greater import in the assessment and diagnosis of personality psychopathology given the “lack of insight” traditionally associated with those diagnosed with personality disorders. An informant-report form also can be used to address other forms of self-report response bias, including both noncredible underreporting and overreporting.

In sum, I am delighted with this set of articles and hope they serve as a generative “springboard” for further research as psychologists move toward an exciting new era in the assessment personality psychopathology.
